title: Mechanic takes council to court after being hit with a massive fine for parking outside his house
text:
A mechanic who took his local council to court to challenge fines for parking on the nature strip in his street has been ordered to pay triple the amount.

Rees Andrew Stephens was fined twice for a total of $208 in September last year for parking on the verge just outside his home in Parkwood, on the Gold Coast.

He said he was justified in parking on the grass as there was no parking on the narrow street at the time, but now has to pay $932 after losing the legal battle.

Rees Andrew Stephens was stung with two parking tickets totalling $208 in September last year for parking on the verge near his home in Parkwood, on the Gold Coast (pictured)

Gold Coast City Council prosecutor Justin Matthews, of QBM Lawyers, told the Southport Magistrates Court on Tuesday Mr Stephens had received a warning notice in the weeks before he was issued the tickets.

Mr Stephens ended up conceding and pleaded guilty to stopping on a nature strip, The Gold Coast Bulletin reported.

Magistrate Andrew Sinclair noted Mr Stephens had not been an extreme inconvenience to a lot of people.

'It's not like he was a commuter, he was parking at home in a suburban street.'

He was fined $208, ordered to pay council costs valued at $599 and an offender levy of $125.80.

When asked outside of court what he thought of the fines, he said; 'A joke … just revenue raising.'
